name: Allison Hill
life_stage: Just ended a 2-year college relationship three months ago; trying to figure out who she is outside of a couple
relevant_history: Downloaded Bumble BFF two weeks after the breakup, matched with four people, had one awkward park hangout that led nowhere, and ghosted the app a week later
emotional_baseline: Cautiously hopeful but emotionally raw; tends to overthink new social situations
in_their_voice: Every app I've tried feels like dating with extra steps, and I can't handle another 'so what do you do' conversation with a stranger.

name: Angie Henderson
life_stage: Six weeks post-breakup from a 3-year relationship; mutual friends chose sides and her social circle shrank overnight
relevant_history: Went to two 'girls night out' events organized via Facebook groups — both felt performatively fun but hollow; she left early both times
emotional_baseline: Quietly lonely but putting on a competent face at work; craves genuine connection but distrusts anything that feels manufactured
in_their_voice: I don't need a bestie fast-track, I just need to stop eating dinner alone every night without it feeling like a whole thing.

name: Noah Rhodes
life_stage: Ended a 2.5-year relationship two months ago; his girlfriend was the social hub of their friend group so he lost the whole network
relevant_history: Tried joining a recreational soccer league to meet people — showed up twice, nobody talked between games, and the group chat was dead outside of scheduling
emotional_baseline: More numb than sad; functioning well at work but notices the silence on weekends acutely
in_their_voice: I joined a sports league thinking I'd make friends and it was basically just running around strangers for an hour and going home.

name: Connie Lawrence
life_stage: Four months out from a 4-year relationship; schedule makes it hard to maintain friendships on top of the breakup disruption
relevant_history: Tried a women's hiking club meetup — showed up alone, everyone already came in pairs, stayed for forty minutes, never went back
emotional_baseline: Exhausted but determined; knows she needs to rebuild but has limited social bandwidth after night shifts
in_their_voice: On the one weekend I'm free, I can't afford to waste it on an event where I'll stand in the corner watching everyone else already know each other.

name: Abigail Shaffer
life_stage: Seven weeks out of a 1.5-year relationship; the breakup was mutual but she still lost the social routines they shared — restaurants, shows, weekend rhythm
relevant_history: Signed up for a pottery class to 'get out there' — enjoyed the pottery but the social dynamic never clicked; too quiet and structured to spark real connection
emotional_baseline: Pragmatic about moving on; feels loneliness in specific moments (Sunday evenings, the walk home) rather than constantly
in_their_voice: I took a class, showed up, made a bowl, talked to no one real — I need something that actually gets people talking, not just occupying the same room.

name: Gina Moore
life_stage: Three months post-breakup from a long-distance relationship that ended when he moved back to the Midwest; she stayed in NYC for her career
relevant_history: Tried Meetup.com for a 'tech women' event — attended once, conversations were entirely networking-flavored, felt more like a LinkedIn interaction than a friendship
emotional_baseline: Intellectually processing the breakup; analytically identifying the gap in her social life but hasn't found the right entry point
in_their_voice: I'm good at analyzing things but I can't analyze my way into a friend group — I need something with actual structure so the awkward part is already handled.

name: Daniel Wagner
life_stage: Five months out from a 3-year relationship; all his friends are coupled up and suddenly unavailable for the random hangouts they used to do
relevant_history: Downloaded Bumble BFF for a week, swiped a bunch, had one coffee that was clearly just two lonely people performing friendship — deleted it
emotional_baseline: Mildly frustrated and slightly embarrassed by how hard he's finding this; doesn't want to make the lack of friends a personality trait
in_their_voice: I'm not looking for a soulmate friend, I just want someone to text when I see something funny — is that somehow impossible to find without an app that feels like Tinder?

name: Gabrielle Davis
life_stage: Two months post-breakup from a 5-year relationship; they lived together, so the breakup reshuffled everything — apartment, friends, routine
relevant_history: Went to three different Meetup events in a one-month burst of energy — a book club, a board game night, a running group — none of them led to a second hangout
emotional_baseline: In a 'doing the work' phase but quietly exhausted by how effortful it all feels; misses having a person to default to
in_their_voice: I've done every suggestion on every listicle about 'how to make friends as an adult' and none of it has worked, so I'm officially skeptical of anything that sounds like advice.

name: Monica Herrera
life_stage: Four months post-breakup from a 4-year relationship; her ex had a huge friend group she was absorbed into — now she's starting from scratch at 28
relevant_history: Joined a book club via Instagram DM from a coworker — went twice, the conversations kept circling back to people she didn't know, and she stopped going
emotional_baseline: Professionally equipped to understand her own grief but personally resisting sitting with it; social activity feels like self-care but hasn't landed yet
in_their_voice: I literally help people build support systems for a living and I still can't figure out how to build my own — the irony is not lost on me.

name: Lisa Hensley
life_stage: Six weeks post-breakup from a 2-year relationship; was planning to move in together when it ended — feels like she's grieving a future as much as a person
relevant_history: Tried a 'women's wellness' social app — got connected to a group chat with eight women, three people were active, nothing ever materialized IRL
emotional_baseline: Busy-grieving: keeping herself slammed with work and plans, running from the quiet moments where the loss is loudest
in_their_voice: Every 'make friends' app I've tried dies in the group chat phase — I don't need more people to text into the void, I need a reason to actually show up somewhere.

name: Cristian Santos
life_stage: Eight months post-breakup but just now feeling the social thinning — his ex moved away and their mutual friends gradually stopped reaching out
relevant_history: Went to a neighborhood trivia night three times — same cliques, same teams, nobody ever invited him in even though he kept showing up
emotional_baseline: Steady on the surface, quietly aware that his social world has been slowly contracting and he needs to actively reverse that
in_their_voice: I kept showing up to the same bar trivia every week and somehow got less integrated each time — consistency apparently doesn't automatically lead to belonging.

name: Michele Williams
life_stage: One year post-breakup from a 6-year relationship; the grief settled but the social infrastructure never rebuilt — she realized recently how thin her independent friend network is
relevant_history: Tried two different 'friend dating' apps over the past year; one died on the matching screen, one got her to coffee with someone nice but they never followed up
emotional_baseline: Clear-eyed and ready to invest in building something real; past the emotional volatility, now just strategically lonely
in_their_voice: I'm not sad anymore, I'm just practically under-connected — I managed my career and my life perfectly fine, I just never rebuilt the friend layer and now I actually notice it.

name: Holly Wood
life_stage: Moved to NYC from Columbus, Ohio three months ago for her first real job; knows approximately two people, both from work
relevant_history: Went to one 'NYC newcomers' Meetup — forty people in a bar, no structure, couldn't hear anyone, left after an hour with zero connections
emotional_baseline: Excited about the city but hit by the loneliness wave that sets in once the novelty fades; FaceTiming home friends more than she expected
in_their_voice: Moving here I thought the hard part was the rent — turns out the harder part is that nobody just becomes your friend, you have to engineer it somehow.

name: Lisa Jackson
life_stage: Moved from Atlanta six months ago; living in Jersey City for the lower rent but finds the PATH train makes NYC feel far when she has no reason to go
relevant_history: Joined a running club that met in Hoboken — did it four times, everyone already knew each other from the previous season, she felt invisible
emotional_baseline: Functioning well professionally but quietly dreading the weekends; describes the loneliness as 'the kind you don't mention because it feels embarrassing to admit'
in_their_voice: I knew moving to a new city would be hard, but I didn't realize how much energy it would take to even get to square one with people — nothing has stuck yet.

name: Carla Gray
life_stage: First-year grad student from Miami; her program cohort is already cliqued-up and she feels behind on building connections outside of class
relevant_history: Signed up for a departmental social event — it was just drinks with her classmates, who she already sees every day; tried a yoga studio but never got past small talk
emotional_baseline: Analytically aware of the problem but emotionally resistant to admitting how much it's affecting her; wants a structured approach but won't call it that
in_their_voice: In Miami I could text ten people any given night — here I'm technically surrounded by people in my program but I've never actually hung out with any of them outside of class.

name: Ryan Munoz
life_stage: Moved from Chicago eight months ago; his firm is small and mostly remote, so work hasn't been the social entry point he expected
relevant_history: Tried two bar trivia nights and a 'finance bros' Meetup group — surface-level conversations, nobody followed up, the whole thing felt like a networking event in disguise
emotional_baseline: Externally easygoing but quietly strategic about fixing his social situation; treats it like a problem with a solution he hasn't found yet
in_their_voice: Everything I've tried has been fine but nothing has actually led to a real hangout — fine doesn't cut it when you've been in a city for eight months with no crew.

name: Patty Perez
life_stage: Relocated from Puerto Rico eighteen months ago to live closer to family, but family lives in a different borough and she's building a social life mostly from scratch
relevant_history: Joined a salsa dancing class hoping to meet people — loved the class but the social connections stayed surface-level and nobody hung out outside of it
emotional_baseline: Warm and social by nature but frustrated by how hard it's been to translate that into actual friendships in this city
in_their_voice: I'm genuinely a people person and still somehow alone most weekends — this city's not unfriendly, it's just that everyone is already in their thing.

name: Judy Baker
life_stage: Moved from Boston a year ago; loves her job but the publishing world is small and incestuous and she wants friends who don't share her professional orbit
relevant_history: Tried a 'books and brunch' social group — good vibe but met only two people she clicked with, one moved away and the other got into a relationship and disappeared
emotional_baseline: Genuinely enjoying the city but aware her social scene is too thin for resilience; wants something more consistent and lower-stakes than organized events
in_their_voice: I've made a friend or two through things I've tried but none of it has turned into a real group — I want the kind of social life where there's always someone to call, not just someone I might text.

name: Stephanie Ross
life_stage: Moved from Pittsburgh two years ago; built some friendships but they were transient — roommates left, work friends got remote — and she's rebuilding again
relevant_history: Has tried Bumble BFF, Meetup, and a neighborhood Facebook group for events — all produced one-off interactions that never deepened into actual relationships
emotional_baseline: Experienced enough with this problem to be pragmatic rather than emotional about it; wants a reliable system, not inspiration
in_their_voice: I've been 'trying things' in this city for two years and I've optimized my way into still being lonely — I need something that builds momentum, not one-off experiences.

name: Jamie Arnold
life_stage: Moved from Denver eighteen months ago; freelance life means no office social gravity, which he underestimated badly
relevant_history: Joined a co-working space hoping it would provide organic social contact — it provided professional networking but zero actual friendship; went to one member happy hour and felt like he was at a pitch event
emotional_baseline: Independent personality who underestimated how much he relied on ambient social connection; not in crisis but aware the problem is real
in_their_voice: Remote work sounds freeing until you realize you haven't had a genuine non-work conversation with anyone in two weeks — I need actual friends, not colleagues I can talk to.

name: Rebecca Henderson
life_stage: Moved from Philadelphia three years ago for a PT position; work is great but her social life never grew past work acquaintances and a couple of drifting friendships
relevant_history: Tried a fitness-focused social app and a neighborhood Slack group — the Slack had 800 members but no events; the app matched her but nobody ever followed through on meeting
emotional_baseline: Patient and measured; has accepted the slower pace of adult friendship-building but wants to accelerate it with something that actually has structure
in_their_voice: I've been in this city three years and my social life is somehow still 'under construction' — I don't need a miracle, I just need something that actually moves things forward.

name: Tricia Valencia
life_stage: Moved from Texas four years ago for a hospital residency; finally has a stable job and apartment but realizes she never built a social life outside of work
relevant_history: Signed up for a cooking class — met one woman she texted with for three weeks, then the conversation died; has tried two similar things with similar results
emotional_baseline: Stable and self-aware; recognizes she has been putting social life last for professional reasons and wants to reverse that prioritization
in_their_voice: I've been telling myself I'd 'figure out my social life' once I got settled — I'm settled, and it turns out settling doesn't automatically generate friends.

name: Debra Davidson
life_stage: Moved from upstate New York five years ago; her original friend group from early NYC years has dispersed — marriages, suburbs, different boroughs — and she's genuinely rebuilding
relevant_history: Has been through the full cycle of trying things — Meetup groups, classes, apps — and gotten skilled at first impressions without ever breaking through to real connection
emotional_baseline: Philosophical about it; knows friendship is structural, not magical, and is looking for a structure that actually works
in_their_voice: I'm very good at meeting people and very bad at turning that into friendship — I've finally accepted that the gap isn't me, it's the format, so I need a better format.

name: Dylan Miller
life_stage: NYC native who lived in San Francisco for four years and just returned; his old friend network has completely scattered and he's rebuilding in a city he thought he knew
relevant_history: Assumed reconnecting with old NYC friends would be easy — it wasn't; people have new lives; tried two Meetup events and felt out of place being the 'returnee' in a newcomer space
emotional_baseline: Slightly disoriented by the experience of being a stranger in his hometown; more motivated than most to fix it but genuinely unsure of the right approach
in_their_voice: Coming back felt like moving to a new city except I didn't have the excuse of being new — everyone assumed I had friends here and I felt too embarrassed to correct them.

name: Sherri Baker
life_stage: One year post-college, tried the NYC social event circuit hard in her first months out and hit a wall; now more selective but more closed-off
relevant_history: Attended seven different social events in three months — bar crawls, gallery openings, rooftop meetups — connected with nobody meaningfully; the volume itself became depressing
emotional_baseline: Deflated and a bit cynical; defaults to solo activities now because at least there's no disappointment attached
in_their_voice: I gave the whole 'put yourself out there' thing a real shot and the events scene is just a rotation of the same people pretending to have more fun than they're having.

name: Brian Ramirez
occupation: entry-level content creator / part-time delivery gig
life_stage: Just out of college, trying to build something in NYC; attempted the social circuit but found it performative rather than connective
relevant_history: Went to a 'young professionals mixer' after seeing it on Instagram — everyone was networking, nobody was actually being themselves; went to two more similar events and had the same experience
emotional_baseline: Energetic but disillusioned; doesn't lack social confidence, lacks environments that reward authenticity over performance
in_their_voice: Every 'social' event I've been to felt like an audition, not a hangout — I just want somewhere I can be an actual person, not a pitch.

name: Cassandra Gaines
life_stage: Moved to Jersey City from DC a year ago; tried the event route because that's what you're supposed to do, got exactly nothing from it
relevant_history: Attended a 'design community' mixer, a women's networking event, and a cultural meetup — left all three within an hour because the vibe was always wrong; transactional, loud, or both
emotional_baseline: Quietly frustrated; believes genuine connection exists but is convinced the event format is the wrong container for finding it
in_their_voice: I've pinpointed exactly what's wrong with every social event I've been to but I still don't know what the alternative is — which is why I'm still looking.

name: Elizabeth Fowler
life_stage: Has lived in Brooklyn for two years; her early attempts to build a social life via events produced surface-level acquaintances but no lasting relationships
relevant_history: Did a 'social fitness challenge' where she attended one event per week for a month — went to bars, trivia nights, dance classes; met twelve new people, texted with two, and is friends with zero of them now
emotional_baseline: Tired of the effort-to-output ratio of social events; looking for something that filters for people who actually want to connect versus people who want to be seen connecting
in_their_voice: I went to so many events that I started recognizing people without knowing their names — we were all doing the same thing and none of us were becoming friends.

name: Brittany Farmer
life_stage: Has been in NYC three years and slowly accepted that the social events she's tried don't lead anywhere; takes a more passive approach now and waits for connection to 'just happen'
relevant_history: Tried book clubs, food tours, and themed bar nights — the book clubs were too intense about the books to be social, the food tours were tourist-heavy, and the bars were just loud
emotional_baseline: Resigned but not defeated; has rationalized the thinness of her social life as 'being selective' but privately knows she's just avoiding the effort
in_their_voice: I've convinced myself I'm an introvert who just needs minimal social contact, but honestly I just stopped trying because nothing I tried actually worked.

name: Derek Zuniga
life_stage: Queens-raised but relocated for a few years and returned; old friend group has grown up and dispersed, tried to rebuild through social events and got frustrated
relevant_history: Attended a gym-social event, a neighborhood block party, and a Meetup for 'fitness enthusiasts' — all pleasant enough but nobody moved from acquaintance to actual friend
emotional_baseline: Physically active and confident in his own skin; frustrated that his ease with strangers doesn't automatically translate to lasting connections
in_their_voice: I can talk to literally anyone but somehow after all these events I have the same number of actual friends as when I started — something is broken in the format.

name: Paula Moreno
life_stage: Has lived in the NYC metro for three years; tried the social event circuit genuinely and came to the conclusion that events select for extroverts who don't need them
relevant_history: Went to five events across different categories — networking, art, fitness, food, games — and every time the same handful of loud people dominated and everyone else stood around
emotional_baseline: Smart and self-aware; doesn't feel desperate but has a clear analytical frustration with how social events actually function
in_their_voice: Social events are designed for people who are already comfortable walking into rooms — if you're looking for a low-stakes entry point they're basically a trap.

name: Sherry Decker
life_stage: Has built a decent but thin social life in Brooklyn; has given up on events as a strategy and relies on workplace relationships that haven't deepened past professional
relevant_history: Tried every format at least once — workshops, panels, bar socials, cultural events — and consistently left feeling more aware of her aloneness than when she arrived
emotional_baseline: Professionally fluent in social dynamics, personally exhausted by applying that knowledge to her own situation; wants something that does the heavy lifting on context
in_their_voice: I spent a year going to things and the only consistent result was a mental list of situations I never want to be in again — whatever this is, it has to be different in kind, not just different in category.

name: Angelica Tucker
life_stage: Has been in NYC five years; early social energy has been replaced by a curated skepticism — she goes to things selectively now but her bar is high
relevant_history: Was once an active event-goer; has slowly filtered down to near zero based on repeated disappointments; the last event she went to she left after thirty minutes and went home to watch TV without regret
emotional_baseline: Comfortable with being selective but aware that her current strategy is 'don't try' rather than 'try the right thing'
in_their_voice: I'm not antisocial — I have great conversations when the context is right — I'm just anti the contexts I've been in, which is everything available.

name: Ethan Adams
life_stage: Has been in Brooklyn six years, knows people around the neighborhood but not deeply; the casual acquaintance layer is thick, the actual friend layer is almost empty
relevant_history: Tried going to tech meetups for a year — all technically social but functionally networking; one board game night that was fun but fell apart logistically after three sessions
emotional_baseline: Comfortable in his routines but aware the social thinning is real; not urgent about fixing it but open to something that doesn't feel like the same formats he's already tried
in_their_voice: I've been at enough meetups to know that 'meetup' is not a friendship, it's a meeting — I need the thing that comes after the meeting and nobody's figured out how to make that happen.

name: Crystal Robinson
life_stage: Has been in Jersey City four years; built a life she likes but the social layer is thin; has tried events regularly without meaningful return
relevant_history: Attended a 'women in healthcare' social, a neighborhood potluck, and two different art events over the past year — pleasant experiences, zero follow-through from anyone
emotional_baseline: Warm and genuinely social when engaged; worn down by the asymmetry of putting energy in and getting nothing back
in_their_voice: I meet people at things and I think we've had a real moment and then they never text and I never text and that's apparently just how adults make zero friends.

name: Shannon Jones
life_stage: Has been in NYC seven years; her early 20s social scene felt abundant but has thinned dramatically as people partnered up, moved, or got buried in work
relevant_history: Her last attempt at social events was eighteen months ago — a series of four or five different formats; came away with nothing tangible; hasn't tried anything since
emotional_baseline: Not desperate but genuinely aware of the gap; would engage with something that seemed credibly different but her prior experience makes her a hard sell
in_their_voice: At some point I stopped going to events because I realized I felt worse after them than before — like they reminded me of the problem without solving it.

name: Jessica Holmes
life_stage: First-year grad student at Columbia; has a tight cohort and active department culture, but the social life feels like a self-contained pod she can't escape
relevant_history: All her current connections are through journalism school — same twelve people at every event; went to one outside social but felt guilty leaving her cohort's orbit for something external
emotional_baseline: Socially active on paper but increasingly aware that 'being around people' and 'having a real social life' are different things
in_their_voice: I have a group chat with my cohort and I see them constantly and somehow I still feel like I'm missing a social life — it's the same twelve people forever.

name: Victoria Garcia
life_stage: Deep in her service year, surrounded by her cohort constantly; the intensity of the work creates closeness but also a bubble she can feel herself calcifying inside
relevant_history: Her social life exists entirely within the AmeriCorps bubble — tried going to a community event outside it once and felt weirdly lost without the shared context
emotional_baseline: Mission-driven and communally oriented; fears becoming someone who can only connect through shared cause and wants to break out before the year ends
in_their_voice: My whole identity this year is 'AmeriCorps person' and I love that but I'm worried that when the year ends I won't know how to be a person outside of it.

name: Tommy Walter
life_stage: One year into his first real job, has a solid work social life but is starting to notice that work friends and actual friends are not the same thing
relevant_history: Relies on his company's happy hours and team events for his social calendar; the one time he tried a non-work social thing (a running club) he felt oddly out of context without colleagues
emotional_baseline: Outwardly social and easy to be around; quietly worried he's built his entire personality around his job and doesn't know what he's like outside of it
in_their_voice: All my actual friends are coworkers, which sounds fine until I think about what happens when I leave this job — I think I need an identity outside of work before that happens.

name: Jessica Callahan
life_stage: Deep in law school's intense social structure; knows everyone in her section, is active in three orgs, and still feels something is missing outside the law school universe
relevant_history: Has tried to make plans outside of law school twice and cancelled both times because school things came up; the bubble is both comforting and limiting
emotional_baseline: High-achieving and plugged in; feels the social ceiling of her institutional context and wants an escape hatch that doesn't require too much energy she doesn't have
in_their_voice: Law school is its own world and I'm fully in it — I need something that pulls me out occasionally without me having to plan the extraction myself.

name: Amber Kidd
life_stage: Has a rich professional community through her work in tech but her personal social life is almost entirely the same set of tech-adjacent people; wants depth outside the bubble
relevant_history: Every social event she goes to is tangentially related to work — tech meetups, startup dinners, community happy hours — has tried zero things that aren't industry-adjacent
emotional_baseline: Gregarious and connected on the surface; privately craving relationships that have nothing to do with what she does for work
in_their_voice: I'm at a social event literally three times a week and I still feel like I don't have friends — because all of it is work, even when it pretends not to be.

name: Tracy House
life_stage: Work provides consistent social structure through team dynamics, but the hospital shifts make maintaining anything outside work logistically hard
relevant_history: Her social life is hospital colleagues; has joined one outside group (a book club through her building) but the scheduling conflict with her shifts killed her participation after a month
emotional_baseline: Pragmatic and resilient; doesn't catastrophize about the social gap but has a clear desire to break out of the hospital-adjacent bubble when logistics allow
in_their_voice: I see my coworkers more than anyone else in the world and I like them fine, but if I had to describe my social life outside of work I'd be describing an empty room.

name: Matthew Foster
life_stage: Deep in his PhD program's social structure; attends department events, knows his cohort well, but the academic bubble is insular and he's aware his non-academic social world is nearly zero
relevant_history: His entire social life is department events, study sessions, and academic conferences; when he's tried to connect outside the program he feels oddly unmoored without the shared context of research
emotional_baseline: Self-reflective and analytically aware of his social situation (which has an ironic quality given his field); genuinely wants to exist outside the academy for a few hours a week
in_their_voice: I study social networks and I can tell you empirically that mine has basically collapsed into one institutional node — which is both professionally interesting and personally embarrassing.

name: Carol Tucker
life_stage: Has been teaching five years; her school community is warm and close but all-consuming, and her social life outside of teacher friends is essentially nil
relevant_history: All her current friendships trace back to school — current colleagues, former colleagues, teacher friends she met at a union event; one attempt at an outside social through a neighborhood app went nowhere
emotional_baseline: Nurturing and socially skilled within familiar contexts; slightly anxious about social situations without a defined role or shared context
in_their_voice: When I'm at school I'm everyone's person, but the second I'm outside of that context I don't know how to introduce myself — I'm just someone with no obvious story.

name: Margaret Hawkins
life_stage: Has worked at the same dental practice for four years; her social world is almost entirely her coworkers, patients, and a church group she goes to occasionally
relevant_history: Her attempts to expand — a community center dance class, a neighborhood Facebook group — both felt like trying to enter a room where everyone had a pre-existing story she wasn't part of
emotional_baseline: Warm and community-oriented; frustrated that the tight contexts she thrives in (work, church) don't have pathways to new people outside them
in_their_voice: I'm a very community-oriented person stuck in the same two communities I've had for four years — I need a way into somewhere new without it feeling like I'm starting over as a stranger.

name: Suzanne Park
life_stage: Has deep community roots through her organization's work but her personal social circle is a subset of professional contacts; the lines between work and social life have blurred almost completely
relevant_history: Every 'friend' she has met through her nonprofit world — volunteers, donors, community partners; has tried once to engage in something purely social and felt purposeless without a mission attached
emotional_baseline: Purpose-driven and highly capable; privately hungry for relationships that are unconditional rather than mission-adjacent
in_their_voice: All my relationships have a layer of purpose attached to them and I've started to wonder if I even know how to just be friends with someone for no reason.

name: Justin Baker
life_stage: Has a tight work team and a fantasy football league with college friends who live in other cities; his Brooklyn social life is a blank page
relevant_history: Hasn't seriously tried to build new local friendships — relies on work colleagues and remote college friends; one attempt at a Brooklyn Meetup felt awkward and he didn't go back
emotional_baseline: Self-sufficient and not in distress; aware the thinness of his local social life will become more apparent as he gets older and wants to address it proactively
in_their_voice: I'm technically fine — I have people to talk to — but they're all either at work or in another city, which eventually is going to be a problem I can't ignore.

name: Natalie Chen
life_stage: Has been in banking for five years; her social life is banker friends from her analyst class who are scattered globally; the ones in NYC are always working or dealing with their own social scarcity
relevant_history: Her entire concept of friendship has been shaped by the banking cohort structure — intense proximity for two years followed by dispersal; has tried to make new friends outside banking twice and found the casual pacing disorienting
emotional_baseline: High-performing and goal-oriented; applying the same structured thinking to her social deficit as she does to her work, which is both effective and a little lonely
in_their_voice: In banking you make intense friends through shared suffering and then everyone scatters — in real life that formula doesn't exist and I have no idea what replaces it.

name: Diana Reyes
life_stage: High school friends moved away or got into serious relationships; college didn't happen; work is her main contact with people and it's not filling the void at all
relevant_history: Has not systematically tried anything — social anxiety has kept her from events; downloaded two apps and deleted them before completing signup
emotional_baseline: Acutely lonely in a way she feels embarrassed to say out loud; the loneliness has started affecting her mood and sense of self-worth
in_their_voice: I work, I go home, I watch TV, I repeat — and I keep telling myself I'll do something about it but I don't, and I don't really know why I don't.

name: Priya Patel
life_stage: Moved from India two years ago for her master's; her cohort was friendly at first but scattered after the first semester; has been socially isolated for most of the second year
relevant_history: Tried an international student group that was warm in the first meeting but faded; a cultural community organization that had events she was too intimidated to attend solo
emotional_baseline: Intelligent and capable but increasingly isolated; the isolation has started to affect her academic performance and mental clarity
in_their_voice: I've been here two years and sometimes I genuinely go three or four days without a real conversation, and that's not okay but I don't know what to do about it.

name: Keisha Williams
life_stage: Her close friend group dissolved when a core member died eighteen months ago; hasn't rebuilt; her work involves caring for others all day while feeling deeply uncared for herself
relevant_history: Made one attempt at a grief support group — wrong format for what she needed; tried a church's social fellowship but felt like an outsider without the religious history
emotional_baseline: Carrying real grief layered under the loneliness; extraordinarily resilient in her work but hasn't found a space to let herself be the one who needs something
in_their_voice: I take care of people all day and then I come home to an empty apartment and there's literally no one to check in on me, and that's been true for over a year now.

name: James Ferrell
life_stage: Moved to NYC from rural Tennessee two years ago to pursue music; the city hasn't been the community he imagined; his musician network is transactional and his non-musician life is empty
relevant_history: Went to open mics hoping to build community — ended up being a regular at two venues but still feels like a stranger in both; the musician social scene feels exclusive in its own way
emotional_baseline: Creatively driven but socially depleted; the romantic image of the artist-in-NYC has given way to genuine loneliness he wasn't prepared for
in_their_voice: I moved here because this city is supposed to be full of people like me, and I found the people like me, and somehow we're all just as alone as we were before we found each other.

name: Simone Ortega
life_stage: A family crisis eighteen months ago reshuffled her entire social world; old friends fell away during a period when she couldn't show up for them, and she hasn't rebuilt
relevant_history: Hasn't tried anything formally — the family situation made her protective of her limited social energy; has been waiting for the 'right time' that never arrives
emotional_baseline: Resilient but running low; knows she needs to actively build something but every day that passes makes the prospect feel more daunting
in_their_voice: I kept saying 'once things calm down' I'd reach out and rebuild, and things calmed down six months ago and I still haven't done it and I'm not sure why.

name: Danielle Kim
life_stage: Fully remote work plus an introversion she has let calcify into true isolation; recognizes she has allowed herself to go weeks without meaningful human contact
relevant_history: Her last real friendship faded during the pandemic and never recovered; has made zero attempts since; the thought of trying feels genuinely frightening now
emotional_baseline: Clear-eyed about the problem, increasingly anxious about the solution; the longer she waits the harder the re-entry feels
in_their_voice: Remote work + pandemic + time passing equals me being someone who has not had a real friend in two years and I am trying to not let that become who I am permanently.

name: Fatima Hassan
life_stage: Completed her PharmD and moved to Jersey City for a job; pharmacy school was the last time she had a ready-made social context and she hasn't rebuilt since
relevant_history: Tried a Muslim community social organization and a professionals network for women of color — both good in theory but the events were infrequent and never led to actual friendships
emotional_baseline: Highly competent professionally; experiences her social isolation as a private shame she doesn't discuss; privately urgent about changing it
in_their_voice: I spent six years in the intensity of pharmacy school making friends by default and now I have to do it on purpose and I genuinely don't know how to do it on purpose.

name: Nathan Maldonado
life_stage: His core friend group from the neighborhood has gradually aged out of hanging out — married, kids, moved to the suburbs; he's stayed and feels left behind
relevant_history: Has not actively tried to build new friendships — everything in his world implied it would happen naturally, and it hasn't; doesn't know where to start at 27 as a working-class guy without a college alumni network
emotional_baseline: Stoic about it but the loneliness is real and has become harder to compartmentalize; doesn't talk about it but acts on it when a low-friction option appears
in_their_voice: All the guys I grew up with have families now and I didn't take that road and suddenly I don't have a road — I need somewhere to start that doesn't feel ridiculous for a grown man.

name: Yuki Tanaka
life_stage: Moved from Osaka three years ago; learned English, built a career, managed everything logistically — social connection is the one thing still missing and she feels it acutely
relevant_history: Tried an expat social group and a Japan Society event — both good in a surface sense but she felt boxed into the 'Japanese expat' identity rather than meeting people as just herself
emotional_baseline: Quietly determined; has achieved everything she set out to do and this is the next clear gap; approaching it with the same methodical energy she brings to her work
in_their_voice: Every social thing I've tried categorized me before I walked in — expat group, Japanese community, international students — I just want to meet people who don't need my nationality to be the starting point.

name: Brianna Scott
life_stage: A depression episode two years ago cost her most of her social relationships; she's been in recovery and building stability but the social layer hasn't come back
relevant_history: Tried a creative community co-working space that felt promising; consistent attendance for a month, then her income got unstable and she had to stop; couldn't restart
emotional_baseline: Carefully fragile in a self-aware way; knows what she needs, knows what she can handle, and is selective because she can't afford to have a bad experience set her back
in_their_voice: I was doing really well and then life interrupted and I lost everything I'd built, and rebuilding from zero when you're already exhausted is harder than anyone admits.

name: Camille Dupont
life_stage: Has been professionally successful but socially passive for most of her 20s; turned 30 and recognized she had built a life with no one in it and felt a genuine jolt of urgency
relevant_history: Tried a social coach app subscription for two months — completed all the prompts, never made a real connection; the guided self-improvement format was not the problem, the missing piece is actual humans
emotional_baseline: Decisive and action-oriented now that she's named the problem; the urgency is real but so is the competence — she will follow through if the path is clear
in_their_voice: Turning 30 made me realize I'd been optimizing my career for a decade while completely ignoring my social life, and the scorecard looks great professionally and genuinely embarrassing personally.

name: Marcus Chen
life_stage: Remote work since the pandemic, rarely leaves his apartment, has not made a single new friend in three years and is only now letting himself register how bad that is
relevant_history: Tried a data science Meetup group — went twice, felt like a work conference, stopped going; was briefly active in a Discord community but found the digital-only format hollow
emotional_baseline: Analytically lucid about the problem but emotionally blocked from acting; knowing the solution doesn't make it feel less scary; the right on-ramp matters a lot for him
in_their_voice: I can tell you statistically exactly how isolated I am and I can explain all the structural reasons why, and none of that has made me one actual friend — knowing the problem isn't the same as solving it.
